review.title: Descriptive-complexity based distance for fuzzy sets
review.abstract: A new distance function dist(A,B) for fuzzy sets A and B is introduced. It is based on the descriptive complexity, i.e., the number of bits (on average) that are needed to describe an element in the symmetric difference of the two sets. The distance gives the amount of additional information needed to describe any one of the two sets given the other. We prove its mathematical properties and perform pattern clustering on data based on this distance.

sections.heading: 2 Information based distances
sections.text: A good distance is one that only picks out the "true" dissidents and ignores factors arising from irrelevant variables or from insignificant random fluctuations that go into the measurements. In most cases, designing a good distance requires designing different distance functions. It can therefore be an expensive process to formulate a good distance, as the words that appear more frequently are less informative.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: This paper introduces a new distance function dist (A, B) for fuzzy sets A, B based on their descriptive complexity. It turns out that the distance is a semimetrist that fulfills the triangular inequality. Compared to other existing distance functions for fuzzy sets, this new measurement is proportional to the additional amount of information needed to describe fuzzy sets A if you know fuzzy sets B or vice versa. Therefore, it has a natural information-based interpretation. Because of this distance, we have shown that fuzzy sets that are summarized tend to be more informative. This is an interesting new property that can be useful for analyzing other data sets.
